title: Max Area of Island
description: You are given an m x n binary matrix grid. An island is a group of 1s (representing land) connected 4-directionally (horizontal or vertical). You may assume all four edges of the grid are surrounded by water. The area of an island is the number of cells with a value 1 in the island. Return the maximum area of an island in grid. If there is no island, return 0.

brute-force.name: DFS
brute-force.description: DFS to calculate area of each island.

steps.instruction: Define the function max_area_of_island that takes grid.

steps.placeholderCode:
rows, cols = len(grid), len(grid[0])
    visit = set()
steps.hint: Get grid dimensions and create a set to track visited cells.
steps.solutionCode:
rows, cols = len(grid), len(grid[0])
    visit = set()

steps.instruction: Define DFS helper to return area.
steps.placeholderCode:
def dfs(r, c):
        if (r < 0 or r == rows or c < 0 or c == cols or
            grid[r][c] == 0 or (r, c) in visit):
            return 0
        visit.add((r, c))
        return (1 + dfs(r + 1, c) + dfs(r - 1, c) +
                dfs(r, c + 1) + dfs(r, c - 1))
steps.hint:
Recursive DFS. Return 0 if invalid or visited. Else, mark visited and return 1 + sum of DFS on neighbors.

Example:
Grid=[[1, 1], [0, 1]].
DFS(0,0): Mark visited. 1 + DFS(0,1) + DFS(1,0)...
  DFS(0,1): Mark visited. 1 + DFS(1,1)...
    DFS(1,1): Mark visited. 1...
Total Area = 1 + 1 + 1 = 3.
steps.solutionCode:
def dfs(r, c):
        if (r < 0 or r == rows or c < 0 or c == cols or
            grid[r][c] == 0 or (r, c) in visit):
            return 0
        visit.add((r, c))
        return (1 + dfs(r + 1, c) + dfs(r - 1, c) +
                dfs(r, c + 1) + dfs(r, c - 1))

steps.instruction: Iterate through grid to find max area.
steps.hint: Loop through all cells, update max area with result of DFS.

    visit = set()

steps.instruction: Iterate through grid to find max area.
steps.hint: Loop through all cells, update max area with result of DFS.
